resources.text: In this task your job is to create program that reads some numbers from a file, and performs some basic statistics on them (according to command line arguments)!
resources.boxed:
This program will read integers from a file called 'numbers.txt', so you'll have to create this file and fill it with numbers first.

Make it so that every number has its own line, like this:

11
-223
43
...

Your program can assume that the file contains only valid integers.
resources.text: The user can tell the program which operations to perform using command line arguments. The following arguments should be supported:
resources.list:
• AVG: passing this argument must make the program calculate the average of the numbers.
  • MAX: passing this argument must make the program calculate the maximum of the numbers.
  • MIN: passing this argument must make the program calculate the minimum of the numbers.
  • RANGE: passing this argument must make the program calculate the range of the numbers.
resources.boxed: If you don't know the meaning of some of these statistical terms, consult online guides! Finding formulas is especially useful, as you can implement these in your program.
resources.text: Allow the user to pass these arguments in any combination. If no argument is given, print an error message and terminate the program. See the code example below to learn how to do so.
resources.boxed: If an invalid argument is given use System.err to notify the user, then stop the program. You can also ignore the invalid argument if you prefer that.
resources.text: Read the numbers from 'numbers.txt'. Using a list is recommended, as the program can't know the amount of numbers in the file!
resources.advanced:
You can use exception handling to handle if the file contains some invalid line that can't be parsed into an integer.

One possible course of action is to skip (ignore) such a line, another is to terminate the program.
resources.text: After reading the numbers, validate if the list is not actually empty!

Print all the numbers to the console. Then, go through the given command line arguments and perform the operations that user requested.

The program must always print which operations it is performing, and the result of this operation.
resources.boxed: It's recommended that you create a method for each statistical operation. They can, for example take the list of numbers as parameters, and return the result!
To compare strings, use the equals method instead of the == operator! The reasons behind this are explained in a later course.

solution.text: One class and a few methods are enough to solve this task. Although the description said that the program can assume that the lines in the file are valid, this solution does not do so. Instead, it removes invalid lines.
solution.code:
package taskstat;

import java.io.IOException;
import java.nio.file.Files;
import java.nio.file.Path;
import java.nio.file.Paths;
import java.util.ArrayList;
import java.util.List;

public class Main {

    public static void main(String[] args) {
         //remove all invalid arguments
         ArrayList<String> validatedArgs = validateArguments(args);
         
         //read the contents of the file into integers
         ArrayList<Integer> numbers = readNumbers();
         
         //print numbers
         System.out.println("The numbers:");
         for(int number: numbers) {
              System.out.print(number + ", ");
         }
         System.out.println();
         
         //perform the statistics
         for(String operation: validatedArgs) {
              if(operation.equals("AVG")) { //average
                   System.out.println("The average is: " + findAverage(numbers));
              } else if(operation.equals("MAX")) { //median
                   System.out.println("The maximum is: " + findMax(numbers));
              } else if(operation.equals("MIN")) { //median
                   System.out.println("The minimum is: " + findMin(numbers));
              } else if(operation.equals("RANGE")) { //range
                   System.out.println("The range is: " + findRange(numbers));
              }
         }
    }
    
    //check the arguments, removing invalid ones.
    static ArrayList<String> validateArguments(String[] args) {
         ArrayList<String> validated = new ArrayList<>();
         
         for(String arg: args) {
              //only keep valid arguments
              if(arg.equals("AVG") || arg.equals("RANGE") ||
                        arg.equals("MAX") || arg.equals("MIN")) {
                   
                   /*
                   We can use the contains method to check if the argument is
                   already added. This way the program will work correctly, even
                   if the user enters the same argument multiple times!
                    */
                   if(!validated.contains(arg)) {
                        validated.add(arg);
                   }
              } else {
                   //notify the user about the invalid argument
                   System.err.println("Invalid argument: " + arg);
              }
         }
         if(validated.size() == 0) { ">//if there aren't any valid arguments
              System.err.println("No valid arguments found!");
              System.exit(0);
         }
         return validated;
    }
    
    //reads the lines and parses them into integers
    static ArrayList<Integer> readNumbers() {
         Path filePath = Paths.get("numbers.txt");
         
         //we must declare it here, so we can use it below the try block
         List<String> lines = null;
         
         try { //this solution uses exception handling
              lines = Files.readAllLines(filePath);
         } catch (IOException e) {
              System.err.println("File reading exception");
              System.exit(0);
         }
         //create empty list of numbers
         ArrayList<Integer> numbers = new ArrayList<>();
         
         //try to parse each line to an integer, and add it to the list
         for(String line: lines) {
              try {
                   numbers.add(Integer.parseInt(line));
              } catch(NumberFormatException e) {
                   continue; ">//ignore the line if it's invalid
              }
         }
         //check if we actually got any numbers
         if(numbers.isEmpty()) {
              System.err.println("No valid numbers in the file!");
              System.exit(0);
         }
         return numbers;
    }
    
    static double findAverage(ArrayList<Integer> numbers) {
         double sum = 0; //calculate the sum of them
         for(int number: numbers) {
              sum = sum + number;
         }
         //the average is the sum divided by the amount of numbers
         return sum / numbers.size();
    }
    
    static int findMax(ArrayList<Integer> numbers) {
         int max = Integer.MIN_VALUE; //start from the lowest possible
         for(int number: numbers) {
              if(number > max) { //we found a larger number
                   max = number;
              }
         }
         return max;
    }
    
    static int findMin(ArrayList<Integer> numbers) {
         int min = Integer.MAX_VALUE; //start from the highest possible
         for(int number: numbers) {
              if(number < min) { //we found a smaller number
                   min = number;
              }
         }
         return min;
    }
    
    static int findRange(ArrayList<Integer> numbers) {
         //the range is the difference between the max and the min numbers
         return findMax(numbers) - findMin(numbers);
    }
}
solution.text: It's worth noting that the Collections utility class has methods for finding maximum and minimum, so the methods can be simplified to this (or they can be replaced by the utility methods):
solution.code:
static int findMax(ArrayList<Integer> numbers) {
    return Collections.max(numbers);
}
    
static int findMin(ArrayList<Integer> numbers) {
    return Collections.min(numbers);
}
